critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer flash their tail to signal danger, warning other deer nearby of potential threats.
critters.activeFact: White-tailed deer flash their tail to signal danger, warning other deer nearby of potential threats.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds!
critters.activeFact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can communicate using howls, yips, and barks to coordinate with their pack during hunts.
critters.activeFact: Coyotes can communicate using howls, yips, and barks to coordinate with their pack during hunts.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes can rotate their ears 180 degrees to better locate sounds and hunt prey efficiently!
critters.activeFact: Red foxes can rotate their ears 180 degrees to better locate sounds and hunt prey efficiently!

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are one of the few canids that can climb trees to escape predators or hunt.
critters.activeFact: Gray foxes are one of the few canids that can climb trees to escape predators or hunt.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats use their sharp vision and hearing to hunt mostly at dawn and dusk, making them skilled predators!
critters.activeFact: Bobcats use their sharp vision and hearing to hunt mostly at dawn and dusk, making them skilled predators!

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines' quills detach easily to protect them from predators, but quills aren‚Äôt actually poisonous!
critters.activeFact: Porcupines' quills detach easily to protect them from predators, but quills aren‚Äôt actually poisonous!

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using branches and mud to create ponds that protect their homes from predators.
critters.activeFact: Beavers build dams using branches and mud to create ponds that protect their homes from predators.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped homes called lodges using plants, creating cozy shelters in wetlands and ponds.
critters.activeFact: Muskrats build dome-shaped homes called lodges using plants, creating cozy shelters in wetlands and ponds.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have waterproof fur that keeps them warm while swimming in cold water.
critters.activeFact: Minks have waterproof fur that keeps them warm while swimming in cold water.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even hunt porcupines by flipping them over!
critters.activeFact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even hunt porcupines by flipping them over!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to 8 minutes while hunting fish!
critters.activeFact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to 8 minutes while hunting fish!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find hidden nuts buried months earlier by using spatial memory and smell!
critters.activeFact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find hidden nuts buried months earlier by using spatial memory and smell!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches to survive harsh winters in North America.
critters.activeFact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches to survive harsh winters in North America.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches to carry food back to their burrows for storage and snacking later!
critters.activeFact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches to carry food back to their burrows for storage and snacking later!

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color from brown in summer to white in winter for camouflage.
critters.activeFact: Snowshoe hares change fur color from brown in summer to white in winter for camouflage.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails have strong hind legs that help them leap up to 10 feet to escape predators.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Cottontails have strong hind legs that help them leap up to 10 feet to escape predators.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws, helping them identify food by touch in water or darkness!
critters.activeFact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws, helping them identify food by touch in water or darkness!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums play dead as a defense, releasing a harmless spray that smells like decay to fool predators!
critters.activeFact: Opossums play dead as a defense, releasing a harmless spray that smells like decay to fool predators!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can accurately spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves.
critters.activeFact: Striped skunks can accurately spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a flap of skin called a patagium, stretching between their legs.
critters.activeFact: Flying squirrels glide using a flap of skin called a patagium, stretching between their legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, making them night‚Äôs tiny, noisy hunters!
critters.activeFact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, making them night‚Äôs tiny, noisy hunters!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, making them natural pest controllers in the wild.
critters.activeFact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, making them natural pest controllers in the wild.

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls hoot ‚ÄúWho cooks for you?‚Äù‚Äîa unique call that helps them find mates and mark territory!
critters.activeFact: Barred Owls hoot ‚ÄúWho cooks for you?‚Äù‚Äîa unique call that helps them find mates and mark territory!

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees to spot prey without moving their bodies.
critters.activeFact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees to spot prey without moving their bodies.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.
critters.activeFact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Male Northern Cardinals are bright red, while females are a warm brown with red accents.
critters.activeFact: Male Northern Cardinals are bright red, while females are a warm brown with red accents.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the year!
critters.activeFact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the year!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice use their crest to communicate mood, raising it when excited or agitated.
critters.activeFact: Tufted Titmice use their crest to communicate mood, raising it when excited or agitated.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that only go upward!
critters.activeFact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that only go upward!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers use their small beaks to drill tiny holes in trees for insects.
critters.activeFact: Downy Woodpeckers use their small beaks to drill tiny holes in trees for insects.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers use their long tongues to extract insects hidden deep inside tree bark.
critters.activeFact: Hairy Woodpeckers use their long tongues to extract insects hidden deep inside tree bark.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers can chisel holes as large as a dinner plate to find insects!
critters.activeFact: Pileated Woodpeckers can chisel holes as large as a dinner plate to find insects!

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers use their strong beaks to drum on trees, marking territory and finding food!
critters.activeFact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers use their strong beaks to drum on trees, marking territory and finding food!

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves are named for their soft, sad cooing that sounds like gentle mourning.
critters.activeFact: Mourning Doves are named for their soft, sad cooing that sounds like gentle mourning.

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, shifting from bright yellow summer to duller winter plumage!
critters.activeFact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, shifting from bright yellow summer to duller winter plumage!

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear nationwide during winter migrations.
critters.activeFact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear nationwide during winter migrations.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are one of the few birds where males' red feathers come from their diet!
critters.activeFact: House Finches are one of the few birds where males' red feathers come from their diet!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches are known for their sweet, warbling songs that fill North American forests in spring!
critters.activeFact: Purple Finches are known for their sweet, warbling songs that fill North American forests in spring!

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can fly up to 55 miles per hour for short distances!
critters.activeFact: Wild turkeys can fly up to 55 miles per hour for short distances!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse use their wings like drums, creating a rhythmic sound called drumming to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: Ruffed Grouse use their wings like drums, creating a rhythmic sound called drumming to attract mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform intricate, graceful dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.
critters.activeFact: Sandhill Cranes perform intricate, graceful dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows use tools like sticks to grab hard-to-reach insects for food.
critters.activeFact: American Crows use tools like sticks to grab hard-to-reach insects for food.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens are one of the smartest birds, known for using tools and solving complex puzzles!
critters.activeFact: Common Ravens are one of the smartest birds, known for using tools and solving complex puzzles!

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks use their keen eyesight to spot prey from over a mile away!
critters.activeFact: Red-tailed Hawks use their keen eyesight to spot prey from over a mile away!

critters.name: Cooper‚Äôs Hawk
critters.fact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile flyers, able to weave through trees to catch birds and small mammals!
critters.activeFact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile flyers, able to weave through trees to catch birds and small mammals!

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are the ancestors of most domestic duck breeds worldwide!
critters.activeFact: Mallard ducks are the ancestors of most domestic duck breeds worldwide!

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are expert nesters, often laying eggs in old tree cavities near water.
critters.activeFact: Wood Ducks are expert nesters, often laying eggs in old tree cavities near water.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, using a distinctive V-formation to conserve energy.
critters.activeFact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, using a distinctive V-formation to conserve energy.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for long periods, patiently waiting to catch fish with their sharp beaks.
critters.activeFact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for long periods, patiently waiting to catch fish with their sharp beaks.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live over 30 years and have brightly colored shells with red, yellow, and black patterns.
critters.activeFact: Painted turtles can live over 30 years and have brightly colored shells with red, yellow, and black patterns.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut in less than 0.1 seconds!
critters.activeFact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut in less than 0.1 seconds!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can quickly change color to blend into their surroundings and avoid predators.
critters.activeFact: Bluegill can quickly change color to blend into their surroundings and avoid predators.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and are popular for sport fishing worldwide!
critters.activeFact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and are popular for sport fishing worldwide!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with vertical dark stripes, making them easy to identify in lakes!
critters.activeFact: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with vertical dark stripes, making them easy to identify in lakes!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can grow over 4 feet long, making them fierce freshwater predators!
critters.activeFact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can grow over 4 feet long, making them fierce freshwater predators!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched peeping calls during early spring nights.
critters.activeFact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched peeping calls during early spring nights.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches and are known for their deep, loud croaks!
critters.activeFact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches and are known for their deep, loud croaks!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators!
critters.activeFact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 10 times their body length to escape predators quickly!
critters.activeFact: Leopard frogs can jump over 10 times their body length to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can live both on land and in water, making them excellent swimmers!
critters.activeFact: Garter snakes can live both on land and in water, making them excellent swimmers!

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting or hiding.
critters.activeFact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting or hiding.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous copperheads with similar colors to deter predators.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous copperheads with similar colors to deter predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to find warmer winter habitats.
critters.activeFact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to find warmer winter habitats.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies can mimic toxic species to avoid predators, using bright colors as a natural warning.
critters.activeFact: Swallowtail butterflies can mimic toxic species to avoid predators, using bright colors as a natural warning.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects!
critters.activeFact: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings over their bodies, unlike dragonflies that keep wings spread out while resting.
critters.activeFact: Damselflies fold their wings over their bodies, unlike dragonflies that keep wings spread out while resting.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, producing light through a chemical reaction in their abdomens.
critters.activeFact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, producing light through a chemical reaction in their abdomens.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates.
critters.activeFact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can fly in cooler temperatures than most bees, helping pollinate early spring flowers.
critters.activeFact: Bumblebees can fly in cooler temperatures than most bees, helping pollinate early spring flowers.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their own body length using powerful hind legs!
critters.activeFact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their own body length using powerful hind legs!
